map_node.indicator_name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
map_node.indicator_description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

dataset.how_calculated: The average number of trucks traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of trucks was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square kilomete
dataset.discription: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.
show_disparities_node.indicator_name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks

Link.graph_title: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks

info.info_name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
info.info_how_calculated: The average number of trucks traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of trucks was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square kilomete
info.info_source: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.

link_data_node.linkDataPagetext: The "Link Data" function shows associations between environmental health data at the neighborhood level using <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Scatterplot" target="_blank">scatterplots.</a> The points represent x and y values for each NYC neighborhood. The pairs of indicators available for scatterplots were chosen because previous research suggests that one may either directly or indirectly cause or contribute to the other. Because the data being charted are <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Ecological_Study" target="_blank">ecological</a> and not individual level, and because many factors contribute to the health of a population or environment, the patterns seen in these charts do not necessarily represent the underlying causal relationship.
link_data_node.indicator_name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood  Fine Particulate Matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) by Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
Compare.y_axis_title: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks - million miles (per km2) 2016
Compare.x_axis_title: Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) - Mean (mcg per cubic meter) Annual Average 2015

info.y_axis_title_reg: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
info.info_how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.
info.info_source: New York City Community Air Survey
